BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Dry slab avalanches and moist avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of snow will fall on Thursday in some localities, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of sleet and the strong westerly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop.
Along the border with France the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Large natural avalanches are likely. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in isolated cases endanger exposed transportation routes.
Low and intermediate altitudes: Moist avalanches are possible. Slides can occur on cut slopes.

As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs will form. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2200 m.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wednesday: 10 to 20 cm of snow fell in the early morning. Thus far the wind has been strong in some localities. The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. Natural avalanches are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 5 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow will fall on Thursday. As a consequence of sleet and the strong westerly wind, a sometimes unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are likely. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in isolated cases endanger exposed transportation routes.
Low and intermediate altitudes: Moist avalanches are possible. Slides can occur on cut slopes.

As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs will form. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wednesday: 10 to 20 cm of snow fell in the early morning.
Thus far the wind has been strong in some localities. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. Natural avalanches are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Some snow will fall over a wide area.
The weather will be cold.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1000 m snow has fallen in some localities. The large surface-area wind slabs can be released easily or naturally on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can over a wide area be released by small loads and reach large size. In the course of the day these will increase in size additionally. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. These avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2200 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures, the activity of dry and moist avalanches will appreciably decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at high altitude. Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Below approximately 2200 m small to medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2400 m. The southwesterly wind has transported the new snow. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
In these regions rain fell up to 2200 m. The rain gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
In all altitude zones only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures, the activity of dry and moist avalanches will appreciably decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the widespread mostly small wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular on steep shady slopes medium-sized natural avalanches must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude brittle wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow will fall until Friday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2000 m.
At high altitude the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Isolated whumpfing sounds can indicate the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1900 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall are lying on surface hoar in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying. The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Little snow will fall over a wide area.
The weather will be cold.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects and above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. These can be released easily by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The soft wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1300 m. The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Little snow will fall over a wide area.
The weather will be cold.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Some natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.

In particular on very steep slopes small to medium-sized natural avalanches are to be expected. Slides can occur on cut slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wednesday: 5 to 15 cm of snow fell in the early morning. Little snow will fall on Thursday.
The wind was strong in some localities. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase a little in all regions at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and has a loosely bonded surface. This applies in particular in shady places that are protected from the wind. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. The rain gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 1200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow in the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are not entirely ruled out.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Weakly bonded old snow at high altitude. Below approximately 1500 m hardly any snow is lying. Above approximately 1500 m a little snow is lying. The weather conditions from the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the old snowpack. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and in places that are protected from the wind. Here small wind slabs formed. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These are shallow and can be released in isolated cases.
